verses.text: Therefore I, a prisoner for the Lord, urge you to walk in a manner worthy of the calling to which you have been called,
verses.comment: Paul appeals as a prisoner, emphasizing the seriousness of his exhortation. The 'calling' refers to God's invitation to live as part of his people.

verses.text: with all humility and gentleness, with patience, bearing with one another in love,
verses.comment: This verse highlights Christian virtues essential for unity in the body, mirroring Christ’s humble example (Phil 2:5–8).

verses.text: making every effort to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace.
verses.comment: Unity is not just an ideal, but a reality given by the Spirit; believers are to protect and maintain it through peace.

verses.text: There is one body and one Spirit, just as you were called to one hope when you were called;
verses.comment: Paul stresses the oneness of the Church, Spirit, and hope—a foundation for apostolic unity (John 17:21).

verses.text: one Lord, one faith, one baptism;
verses.comment: Emphasizes that baptism is the entry into Christ’s body and the unity of faith under the lordship of Christ.

verses.text: one God and Father of all, who is over all and through all and in all.
verses.comment: The Father’s presence permeates creation and the people of God. An expression of God’s immanence and transcendence.

verses.text: But grace was given to each one of us according to the measure of Christ’s gift.
verses.comment: Though united, believers receive diverse gifts from Christ, underlining both unity and variety in the Church.

verses.text: Therefore it says, “When he ascended on high, he led a host of captives, and he gave gifts to men.”
verses.comment: A quotation adapting Psalm 68:18, seen as fulfilled in Christ’s ascension and outpouring of spiritual gifts.

verses.text: Now in saying, “He ascended,” what does it mean but that he also descended into the lower regions of the earth?
verses.comment: This refers to Christ's incarnation and descent to earth, understood by tradition also as his descent to the dead after death (see the Apostles’ Creed).

verses.text: He who descended is the one who also ascended far above all the heavens, so that he might fill all things.
verses.comment: Christ’s ascent is his exaltation, and his filling ‘all things’ points to his unique lordship over all creation.

verses.text: And he gave some to be apostles, some prophets, some evangelists, some shepherds and teachers,
verses.comment: The variety of ministries point to Christ’s care for his people through authoritative and teaching offices, foundational for the visible Church.

verses.text: to equip the saints for the work of ministry, for building up the body of Christ,
verses.comment: Church ministries exist to perfect and build up believers, stressing the need for organized ministry.

verses.text: until we all reach the unity of the faith and of the knowledge of the Son of God, to mature manhood, to the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ,
verses.comment: The Church grows toward unity and maturity in Christ—a lifelong communal process, not a merely individual pursuit.

verses.text: so that we may no longer be children, tossed to and fro by the waves and carried about by every wind of teaching, by the cunning of men in their craftiness, with deceitful schemes.
verses.comment: Sound doctrine and the Church’s structure protect believers from error and spiritual instability.

verses.text: But speaking the truth in love, we are to grow up in every way into him who is the head, Christ,
verses.comment: Growth in Christ is achieved through truth joined with love. Christ is the head—a metaphor for both authority and source of life for the Church.

verses.text: from whom the whole body, joined and held together by every supporting ligament, grows and builds itself up in love, as each part works properly.
verses.comment: The life and unity of believers depends on remaining connected to Christ through the visible structure of the Church.

verses.text: Now I say this and insist on it in the Lord, that you must no longer walk as the Gentiles do, in the futility of their minds.
verses.comment: Paul urges a distinct Christian way of life, separate from pagan ways of thinking.

verses.text: They are darkened in their understanding, alienated from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them, due to the hardness of their hearts.
verses.comment: Sin blinds and separates people from God. Conversion requires both God’s grace and openness of heart.

verses.text: They have become callous, and have given themselves up to sensuality, greedy to practice every kind of impurity.
verses.comment: Unchecked sin leads to greater depravity. Christian life calls for discipline, not self-indulgence.

verses.text: But that is not the way you learned Christ—
verses.comment: 'Learned Christ' shows Christianity is centered not just on teaching, but a living relationship and imitation of Christ Himself.

verses.text: if indeed you have heard him and were taught in him, as the truth is in Jesus,
verses.comment: Christ himself is the Truth; to hear the Church’s message is to hear him (Luke 10:16).

verses.text: to put off your old self, which belongs to your former way of life and is corrupt through deceptive desires,
verses.comment: Baptism and repentance involve a decisive turning from the old life and its passions.

verses.text: and to be renewed in the spirit of your minds,
verses.comment: Renewal is inward, a work of the Holy Spirit empowering believers to think and act according to God’s will.

verses.text: and to put on the new self, created after the likeness of God in true righteousness and holiness.
verses.comment: ‘Putting on the new self’ alludes to salvation as a recreation, restoring the image of God lost in the Fall.

verses.text: Therefore, having put away falsehood, let each one of you speak the truth with his neighbor, for we are members one of another.
verses.comment: Living truthfully safeguards the unity and harmony of the Christian community.

verses.text: Be angry and do not sin; do not let the sun go down on your anger,
verses.comment: Anger is not inherently sinful, but must never lead to sin or be allowed to linger, endangering the soul.

verses.text: and do not give an opportunity to the devil.
verses.comment: Unresolved anger can become a foothold for evil. Spiritual vigilance is necessary.

verses.text: Let the thief no longer steal, but rather let him labor, doing honest work with his own hands, so that he may have something to share with anyone in need.
verses.comment: Redemption brings transformation; charity is a hallmark of Christian life, following Christ’s example.

verses.text: Let no corrupt talk come out of your mouths, but only such as is good for building up, as fits the occasion, so that it may give grace to those who hear.
verses.comment: Speech is to be a means of grace; this is an imperative grounded in Christ’s sanctifying presence.

verses.text: And do not grieve the Holy Spirit of God, by whom you were sealed for the day of redemption.
verses.comment: Believers are marked as God’s own through the Holy Spirit, who remains with them until final salvation.

verses.text: Let all bitterness and wrath and anger and clamor and slander be put away from you, along with all malice.
verses.comment: All destructive attitudes—especially those that harm fellowship—are to be rejected, furthering peace in the Christian community.

verses.text: Be kind to one another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, just as God in Christ forgave you.
verses.comment: Forgiveness is essential because it imitates Christ’s ultimate act of mercy. This verse prepares for a discussion of sacramental life in the next chapter.
